chapterMeaning: The Yoga of Royal Knowledge and Royal Secret
sanskrit:
मन्मना भव मद्भक्तो मद्याजी मां नमस्कुरु।
मामेवैष्यसि युक्त्वैवमात्मानं मत्परायणः।।
transliteration:
man-manā bhava mad-bhakto mad-yājī māṁ namaskuru |
mām evaiṣyasi yuktvaivm ātmānaṁ mat-parāyaṇaḥ ||
translation: Fix your mind on Me, be devoted to Me, worship Me, and bow down to Me. Thus, uniting yourself with Me and making Me your supreme goal, you shall certainly come to Me.
commentary:
This concluding verse of Chapter 9 encapsulates the essence of bhakti yoga (the path of devotion) in four simple yet profound instructions. Krishna presents a complete spiritual practice: fixing the mind on the Divine (man-manā), cultivating devotion (mad-bhakta), performing worship and sacrifice (mad-yājī), and offering reverence through prostration (namaskuru). These four practices represent the integration of thought, emotion, action, and surrender—the complete engagement of one's being in spiritual life.

The verse promises definite results: 'mām evaiṣyasi' (you shall certainly come to Me). This assurance is conditional upon 'yuktvā ātmānam' (uniting yourself) and being 'mat-parāyaṇa' (having Me as the supreme goal). The certainty of the promise reflects Krishna's confidence in the efficacy of devotion when practiced with complete commitment. This verse emphasizes that spiritual success is not uncertain or dependent on complex rituals, but is guaranteed through sincere, wholehearted devotion.

This verse serves as both a summary of the Raja Vidya (Royal Knowledge) discussed throughout the chapter and a practical instruction for implementation. It bridges the philosophical teachings about Krishna's divine nature, His manifestations, and His relationship with creation, with concrete spiritual practice. The simplicity of the instruction makes it accessible to all seekers regardless of their intellectual capacity or social position, reinforcing the chapter's earlier message that devotion is available to everyone. This verse is often cited as one of the most important in the Gita for practitioners of bhakti yoga.
speaker: Krishna
